The on-purpose production of butadiene and light olefins via oxidative conversion of n-butane was investigated over nanocomposites of Ni-Bi-Si oxides comprising Bi12SiO20/Bi2SiO5 phase regulated with silica of Beta, USY and ZSM-5 zeolites. Different ratios of Bi12SiO20 and Bi2SiO5 phases were obtained depending on the zeolite species and its SiO2/Al2O3 ratio. The Ni-Bi-Si oxides were characterized by X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, etc. to examine the electronic state and oxygen mobility in specific Bi-Si oxides; Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20. The active species-zeolites interaction controlled the reducibility of Ni-Bi-O system and acidity of the catalysts. Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500) catalyst exhibited high selectivity for the oxidative conversion of n-butane to ethylene and propylene (60.7 wt. %) at 16 % conversion. Similarly, the olefinic selectivity over NiO-Bi12SiO20-Bi2SiO5/ZSM-5(280) catalyst at 20 % conversion, was 87 % (ethylene and propylene = 28.3 %, C4 olefins = 58.6 % including BD = 20 %) at 500°C and feed ratio of O2/n-butane = 2.0. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Oxidative cracking n-butane Zeolite catalyst Bi12SiO20 Ethylene propylene 1 Introduction Steam cracking of naphtha is the main source of light olefins (ethylene and propylene) and 1,3 butadiene (by-product extracted from C4 product stream). Light olefins are mainly used in the production of various polymers for the packaging industry while 1,3 butadiene (BD) is widely used in the manufacture of synthetic rubber and resins. The catalytic conversion of n-butane to light olefins and BD is an alternative to steam cracking of naphtha with added environmental benefits due to reduced carbon emissions. Conventional dehydrogenation of n-butane has been commercialized for the production of butene, however, the process requires high temperature associated with frequent catalyst regeneration [1]. Improved processes using olefins with oxidants (oxygen, steam) as co-feed to produce BD have also been reported [2–5]. The utilization of oxygen as co-feed in n-butane oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reduces catalyst deactivation and is operated at lower temperatures thereby removing thermodynamic equilibrium limitation [6–8]. Several researchers have used various catalyst systems to investigate the dehydrogenation and/or ODH of n-butane to primarily butenes [9–16]. In these studies, the successive dehydrogenations (1st and 2nd) selectivities to BD were not well explored. Our previous studies on the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane [17–19] showed high selectivity to butenes (up to 78.3 %) and BD (up to 41.6 %) at 35.6 % n-butane conversion using metal oxides of Ni and Bi supported on Al2O3 and SiO2. We have also investigated the role of mesoporous supported silica catalysts in improving the dispersion of metal oxides with an improved performance of 47.5 % selectivity to BD at 29 % conversion [20]. Kaliaguine and coworkers were the first to report the cooperation of simple bismuth oxide with mesoporous and microporous silica for the oxidation of liquid hydrocarbons [21]. They concluded that Bi exhibited a promoter effect that generated new active centers for adsorbing oxidizing (OH) species. Other authors also reported the concept of the simple BiOx species interacting with the support for mainly photocatalytic and oxidation reactions [22–26]. Mesoporous supports interacted positively with the bismuth oxides species (BiOx) thereby forming bismuth silicates (Bi2SiO5), while several authors already confirmed this Bi2SiO5 phase formation [27–31]. However, we established that the degree of formation of bismuth silicate (Bi2SiO5) influenced the selectivity to the desired BD during n-butane ODH, via changing the dispersion and reducibility properties of active NiO species [32,33]. The selectivities to butenes and butadiene were 71.4 % and 49.4 %, respectively, at 30 % n-butane conversion. In this study, the advanced concept of bismuth oxide-support interaction based on the formation of bismuth silicate species (Bi2SiO5) inside mesoporous silica was used to investigate the interaction effect of various zeolites including beta, ultra-stable Y (USY) and ZSM-5 with bismuth oxide. Intermediate type of bismuth silicate between Bi2SiO5 and beta-Bi2O3 was newly identified using XRD as Bi12SiO20. The role of Bi12SiO20 phase in the catalysts was studied for the oxidative conversion of n-butane to 1,3-butadiene and light olefins. The cooperation effect through the bismuth silicate phase between the zeolite supports and the metals oxides of Ni and Bi was revealed as nanocomposite catalysts of Ni-Bi-Si oxides on Beta, USY and ZSM-5 zeolites. The role of Ni-Bi-Si oxides/zeolite nanocomposite catalysts was to control the product selectivity for the oxidative conversion of n-butane to high-value products. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Various zeolites were used in this study as catalyst supports comprising Beta (SiO2/Al2O3 =100), USY (SiO2/Al2O3 =15) and ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 1500). They were purchased from Tosoh Corporation as HSZ-960HOA, HSZ-360HUA and HSZ-890HOA, respectively. ZSM-5 zeolite samples (SiO2/Al2O3 = 23, 80 and 280) were purchased from Zeolyst International as CBV2314, CBV8014 and CBV28014, respectively. Metal precursors for Ni and Bi [i.e. Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (99%) and Bi(NO3)3.5H2O] were purchased from Fisher-Scientific and Fluka-Garantie, respectively. Wet nitrate co-impregnation method was used to prepare the Ni-Bi-O/supported catalysts. Ni (20 wt%)-Bi (30 wt%) oxides supported catalysts were prepared by first dissolving Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (0.99 g) in distilled water (100 mL), then adding Bi(NO3)3.5H2O (0.70 g) while stirring the resulting solution. The dried zeolite support (1.0 g) was introduced for impregnation and stirred for 2 h with a magnetic stirrer (500 rpm) to obtain a homogeneous mixture. Subsequently, water was removed using a hot plate with stirring at 50°C. The mixture was then calcined after being dried overnight at 100°C. Calcination of the as-prepared catalysts was performed in two stages. At the initial stage, the temperature was increased up to 350°C (ramping rate of 10°C min−1) and maintained for 1 h. In the 2nd stage, the temperature was increased to 590°C (ramping rate of 15°C min−1) and maintained for 2 h in order to achieve complete stabilization and activation. The resulting catalyst containing 20 wt% Ni as metal-30 wt% as metal Bi-O/zeolite was crushed, pelletized and sieved into mesh granules of 500-850 μm. The same procedure was used to prepare all the catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Various analytical techniques were used to characterize the supports and metal-impregnated catalysts. The textural features were measured using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument (Norcross, GA). The BET equation was used to measure the surface areas using linear region of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (p/p0 = 0.05-0.1). Pore properties were estimated utilizing BJH adsorption method. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by Rigaku Miniflex II by the use of Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å) at 15 mA, 30 kV, 0.02° step size and a 2° min−1 scan speed from 5° to 90° range for 2θ. 2θ = 10 to 50° was selected to examine the phases of Bi oxides carefully. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) measurements were performed using ESCALAB™ XI+ spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic aluminum Kα X-ray source (hα = 1486.68 eV) operated at 150 W. The electronic state and distribution of metal oxide species in the catalysts were investigated using XPS with an energy step size of 0.1 eV. UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were obtained using V750 JASCO, spectrophotometer. 50 mg of catalyst sample was placed over diameter integrated sphere (60 mm) and analyzed at room temperature from 200-800 nm wavelength. High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100F) operating at 200 kV was used to examine crystal size, morphology, and active species dispersion. The samples were made by dispersing powder samples in ethanol, sonicating them and then dropping them onto a carbon film grid. The redox behavior and acid-base strength of the catalysts were investigated utilizing temperature programmed techniques; Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and Temperature programmed desorption (TPD), respectively, using BELCAT-A-200 chemisorption instrument. This unit comprises quartz holder, heating furnace, mass spectrometer and thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The linearity of the TCD response using helium in the background flow is described by a gas pulse injection with a standard volume. The redox behavior was estimated using a gas mixture of Ar/H2 (95/5 vol%) with a flowrate of 50 mL min−1. Initially, calcined catalyst (0.1 g) was pre-heated for 3 h at 300 °C in the presence of inert He, later it was cooled down to ambient temperature. After which, the sample was further heated up to 1000 °C (20 °C min−1). H2 consumption was recorded from TCD and CuO (reference) was used for calibration of H2 utilization. NH3 and CO2 temperature programmed desorption studies were conducted to measure acidity and basicity using the BELCAT system. Calcined catalysts (0.1 g) were subjected to 500 °C for 1 h using inert He (stream flow rate of 50 mL min−1). The sample was subjected to He/NH3 (He/CO2 for CO2-TPD) with 95/5 vol% at temperature 100 °C for 30 minutes. Gaseous ammonia or carbon dioxide was extracted by He purging for 1 h. The TPD was carried out with a similar He flow until 600 °C (stream rate of 10 °C min−1). Gaseous desorbed ammonia or carbon dioxide was measured by means of mass spectroscopy or TCD. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation Catalytic performance tests for n-butane oxidative conversion reactions were carried out using the MicroTrac Bel Company's fixed-bed flow reactor system. The reactor was packed with 0.3 g of the catalyst sieved to 500-850 µm particle size and the reaction was conducted in nitrogen environment. n-Butane contact time was maintained at 0.42 g-cat h/mol-C4. The overall reactant stream flow-rate (nitrogen/n-butane/air in the ratio 18/1.2/12 mL min−1, respectively) was 31.2 mL min−1. Specific temperatures (450 and 500 °C) and O2/n-butane proportion (2.0 mol/mol) were investigated for 1 h each. The products were examined using an online gas chromatograph system (Agilent, 7890N). Oxygenates and hydrocarbons were measured in a GC-Gas Pro (internal diameter: 0.32 mm and length: 60 m) and capillary column flame ionization detector, respectively. Thermal conductivity detector and ShinCarbon 80/100 mesh column SS (He carrier) and MS5A 60/80 mesh column SS (Ar carrier) were utilized to identify gases such as CO, O2, N2, CO2 and H2. Standard samples were used to confirm the products. n-Butane conversion and selectivities to products were calculated using the following expressions. Butane conversion ( % ) = moles of butane fed − moles of butane in the product moles of butane fed x 100 Product selectivity ( % ) = moles of product butane conversion x 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Pore structure and surface area The pore size distributions for the parent zeolites, Beta, USY, ZSM-5(80) and their corresponding Ni-Bi-O loaded catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 (a, b and c), respectively. The pore size distributions of Beta and ZSM-5(80) supports depicted narrow sharp peak around 3.8 nm, while USY support exhibited two peaks around 3.8 nm and 23 nm. The peaks for the three supports slightly changed after Ni-Bi-O loading. Similarly, the pore size distribution of ZSM-5 (280) and (1500) and their Ni-Bi-O metal oxides impregnated catalysts as depicted in Figure S4 showed slight differences. These indicate that the pore structures were not significantly affected by the metal oxides impregnation. Fig. 2 shows pore size distribution for catalysts of Ni-Bi-O loaded on ZSM-5 with various SiO2/Al2O3 ratios. ZSM-5(23) and ZSM-5(80) showed mesopores around 3.8 nm, while ZSM-5(280) and ZSM-5(1500) showed mesopores around 2.2 nm and 2.0 nm, respectively. All the mesopores in the Ni-Bi-O loaded ZSM-5 catalysts originated from parent zeolites. The physical properties of all the parent zeolites and metal-impregnated catalysts are presented in Table 1 . The nanocomposite formation was observed in the pore structure of the catalysts from the parent Beta, USY, and ZSM-5(80) zeolites. Based on catalyst weight, all catalysts had a significant decrease in surface area as compared to the support, while based on parent zeolite weight, a small decrease in surface area for Beta and ZSM-5 with a slight increase for USY were observed. Beta and ZSM-5 supported catalyst have enlarged pore properties (pore diameter and pore volume) compared with the parent zeolite, while USY supported catalyst has narrowed pore diameter relative to the parent zeolite. This is probably due to the different affinity of the metal species with SiO2 dissolution of the USY compared to the Beta and ZSM-5 supports. The physical properties of ZSM-5 supports having different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios and their corresponding catalysts are presented in Table S1 (supporting information). All ZSM-5 supported catalysts have a reduced surface area compared to their corresponding supports. This is due to the filling of the various supports channels by the metal oxides. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD patterns of parent zeolite supports (Beta, USY, and ZSM-5) and loaded Ni-Bi-O/zeolite catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 (a, b and c). The main phase identified for the Ni-Bi-O/Beta, USY and ZSM-5(80) catalysts is Bi2SiO5 at 2θ = 28.95°, which agree with earlier report on Ni-Bi-O/mesoporous silica SBA-15 [32,33]. The characteristic peaks associated with this phase are observed at 2θ = 28.95°, 32.33° and 33.38° which corresponds to (311), (020) and (002) diffraction lines, respectively [34]. Furthermore, new phase with characteristics peaks at 2θ = 27.72°, 33.48°, and 46.6° was also observed, corresponding to Bi12SiO20 phase (JCPDS 00-037-0485). The robust interaction of BiOx species and SiO2 from the zeolites resulted in this phase formation. The diffraction lines associated with the peaks of this phase are (310), (321) and (510), respectively. The new phase identification as Bi12SiO20 agreed well with the literature report by Gu et al. [35]. The Bi12SiO20 compositionally exists as an intermediate type of bismuth silicate between Bi2SiO5 and beta-Bi2O3. In all catalysts, bismuth silicate phases (Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20) are formed confirming the crystallographically strong interaction between BiOx impregnated as metal oxide and SiO2 present in the zeolites support. The formation of bismuth silicate phases (Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20) were further confirmed using ZSM-5 with various SiO2/Al2O3 ratios. The XRD patterns of the loaded Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 catalysts are presented in Fig. 4 . The ratio of bismuth silicate phases (Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20) changes with SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of ZSM-5. The bismuth silicate phase Bi12SiO20 dominates at SiO2/Al2O3 ratios of 23 and 1500. Bi2SiO5 dominates at SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 80 and both Bi12SiO20 and Bi2SiO5 are nearly equivalent at SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 280. For the XRD peak ratio of bismuth silicate phases (Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20), each phase percentage and Si/(Bi+Si) ratio as Si content of the bismuth silicate are summarized in Tables 2 and 3 . Lower peak intensity may be attributed to smaller crystal size or higher dispersion, rather than just lower amounts. However, it was confirmed that in all catalysts, the Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20 phases’ peaks appeared near 2θ with similar crystal sizes as determined by half height width using the Scherrer equation as presented in Table S2. According to the zeolite type, the order of Bi12SiO20 formation was Beta < ZSM-5 < USY. For the ZSM-5 zeolites of different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios, Al-rich ZSM-5(23) produced bismuth silicate (Bi12SiO20) due to the competition between Bi-O-Si and Bi-O-Al bonds, ZSM-5(80) produced bismuth silicate (Bi2SiO5), Si-rich ZSM-5(280) produced nearly equal proportions of both Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20, and high-Si ZSM-5(1500) produced bismuth silicate (Bi12SiO20) mainly due to the inhibited desilication caused by Ni and Bi nitrate during calcination. The different trends of bismuth silicates with Si/Al ratios for ZSM-5, and across the different zeolite types is due to the different interactions of bismuth oxides with the Si in the zeolites framework As for the NiO species, XRD peaks with intensity around 2θ = 36.98° and 43.1° were observed for all catalysts. This indicates that, the particles of NiO phase is dispersed as nanosize in nanocomposite of Bi silicates on the zeolite supports. Based on XRD measurements, Ni-Bi-O loaded ZSM-5(80) and ZSM-5(1500) catalysts were selected for further characterizations using XPS, UV-vis DRS and HRTEM as the representative samples of bismuth silicates; Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20, respectively. 3.1.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to investigate both electronic state and the distribution of metal oxide species in the catalysts. The XPS technique with an Ar-etched process was utilized not only to remove the surface adsorbed species but also to confirm the observation focused on the impregnated surface layer. The XPS survey spectra for Ni-Bi-O loaded ZSM-5(80) and ZSM-5(1500) catalysts are shown in Fig. S1 and S2, confirming the presence of Si 2p, Bi 4f, O 1s, and Ni 2p peaks. Fig. 5 depicts the XPS spectra of the bismuth silicate elements Bi, Si, and O for ZSM-5 supported catalysts. Fig. 6 presents spectra of Ni XPS as active sites supported and dispersed on bismuth silicate. The spectra of the upper and lower layers were measured as the outer and inner surfaces before and after etching, respectively. Since the spectra are similar between the outer and inner surface, the spectrum of the inner surface was used as the impregnated surface layer for the discussions. Fig. 5a and Fig. 5d show the Bi 4f XPS spectra for Ni-Bi-O loaded ZSM-5(80) and ZSM-5(1500) catalysts, respectively. The peaks of Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80) at binding energies of 161.2 and 166.7 eV, and that of Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500) at 162.0 and 167.2 eV represent Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 species, respectively. These binding energies are assumed to be for Bi3+ from Bi–O–Bi bonds in Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20, even though the values are higher than the binding energies of Bi3+ bismuth for pure Bi2O3 (158.3 and 163.8 eV) [32]. As for the peaks of Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80), the intensity from the outer is larger than the inner, while this difference was not observed at Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500). This observation suggests that the Bi-O-Bi layer in Bi12SiO20 also exists in the Bi2SiO5, especially around the outer surface. The major peak at binding energy of 156.0 eV for Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80) is assumed to be Bi3+ from Bi–O–Si bonds in Bi2SiO5. The difference in binding energies could be attributed to the Bi–Si interaction, which causes electron density splitting around bismuth. This demonstrates that the Bi2SiO5 bismuth layer in Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80) catalyst is in strong interaction with silica layer. Bi3+δ+ and Bi3+δ− states are formed by layered Bi–O–Si bond. On the other hand, the Bi12SiO20 in Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500) catalyst is in Bi3+ matrix more oxidized by dispersed Si4+ without the splitting of electron density around bismuth. Fig. S3 shows the comparison for Bi XPS spectra for Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 catalyst with different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios. The Si 2p XPS spectra for Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80) and ZSM-5(1500) catalysts are shown in Fig. 5b and 5e. The peaks of Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80) and ZSM-5(1500) appear at binding energy of 105.38 and 105.78 eV, respectively which demonstrates that the Si species of Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20 are at the Si4+ state, however, the Si species of Bi12SiO20 is more positive (δ+) than that of Bi2SiO5. This accelerates the mobility of the oxygen species in Bi12SiO20 into Ni oxide as the active site. As evidenced by the Bi 4f and Si 2p XPS peaks, Bi and Si species in Bi12SiO20 are both more oxidized than those in Bi2SiO5. This fact suggests the existence of counter species such as anion and/or reduced element in Bi12SiO20. The XPS O 1s spectrum of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 5c and 5f. It is interesting to note that two clear distinct peaks were observed in the Bi12SiO20 of Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500), while one peak at the higher binding energy was observed in the Bi2SiO5 of Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80). The two binding energy peaks of pure Bi12SiO20 phase have been reported at 529.6 eV and 531.3 eV [36–38]. The peak with binding energy position at 529.6 eV was assigned to the mobile oxygen as the counter species, whereas the other peak observed at 531.3 eV could be related to the less mobile oxygen in the lattice. Binding energy values for all Bi 4f, Si 2p, and O 1s matched, and Bi12SiO20 phase was assigned based on XRD results. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum for Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80) and ZSM-5(1500) catalysts are shown in Fig. 6a and 6b, respectively. The Ni 2p3/2 species showed peaks with 855.9 eV and 855.7 eV binding energies for both catalysts, which are in agreement with the reference of NiO [39], which XRD result identified as NiO nanoparticles. Compared to outer surface for Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80), the Ni species exhibited XPS peaks (856.6 eV) with a 0.7 eV drop in binding energy. These changes demonstrated a tandem co-habitation between NiO and Bi12SiO20 nanoparticle species on ZSM-5 zeolite support. This also directed the charge transfer between NiO and Bi silicate as reported earlier [32]. 3.1.4 UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) The mobile oxygen in the Bi12SiO20 of Ni-Bi-O/supported catalysts was confirmed using UV-vis DRS. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), all the Ni-Bi-O/supported catalysts (Beta, USY and ZSM-5) exhibit UV absorption with a wavelength less than 385 nm which is assigned as Bi2SiO5 phase confirmed using XRD result [40]. Fig. 7(b) represents the UV-vis DRS for the representative Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(80) and ZSM-5(1500) catalysts. A broad continuous absorption band between 300-800 nm was observed in the Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 catalyst with SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 1500, confirming the existence of Bi12SiO20 phase [41]. 3.1.5 High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) The effect of Bi silicates (Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20) phases on crystal size, morphology and active species dispersion was confirmed by HRTEM as presented in Fig. 8 . Bi2SiO5 nanoparticles are layered crystalline in shape and Bi12SiO20 nanoparticles are highly dispersed (Fig. 8 (a) and 8 (c)). The lattice distance of NiO is 0.15 nm, which corresponds to the NiO plane (220), consistent with previous studies [42]. NiO particles in Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 catalysts, coexisted with the Bi species. It thus signifies that the oxides 1) Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20 are well-ordered on the zeolite, and 2) a hierarchically layered catalyst system is formed by top NiO species distributed on Bi silicate species supported on zeolite. 3.1.6 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) During oxidative dehydrogenation reactions, the reducibility of the catalyst active oxides determines catalytic activity. To estimate the reducibility of active species, TPR was used Fig. 9.(a) and Fig. 9(b) depict the H2-TPR profiles for the Ni-Bi-O/zeolite catalysts and Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 of various SiO2/Al2O3 ratios. As shown in Fig. 9(a), both Ni-Bi-O/Beta and Ni-Bi-O/USY catalysts revealed a reduction peak centered around 500-600°C, while Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 catalyst produced a wide reduction peak ranging from 400-700°C. On the other hand, as shown in Fig. 9(b), Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 catalysts of various SiO2/Al2O3 ratios changed the TPR profiles along the ratio. A double peak of easily reducible and less reducible species was observed in the Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500) catalyst, confirming the interaction of NiO on Bi12SiO20 phase [41]. However, the most dynamic change in TPR profile was observed for the Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(280) catalyst, which exhibited the most easily reducible pattern. The reducibility was assumed to originate from the interaction of NiO with the equivalently mixed phases of Bi12SiO20 and Bi2SiO5 at the phase boundary, known as a reduction interface. All the species contributed to the total reduction, which also confirmed the importance of surface heterogeneity [43]. 3.1.7 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) The acidity of the metal-loaded catalysts was measured using NH3-TPD technique as presented in Fig. 10 (a) and (b). The NH3-TPD profiles were deconvoluted into three peaks in the ranges of 100-300 °C, 300-450 °C and above 450 °C, defined as I: weak acid, II: moderate acid and III: strong acid. The acidic sites in terms of the amount of NH3 desorbed through the entire range of strong, moderate, and weak acid sites increased as follows a) zeolite species: 20Ni-30Bi/USY ∼ 20Ni-30Bi/Beta < 20Ni-30Bi/ZSM-5(80) and b) Ni-Bi-O on ZSM-5(1500) < ZSM-5(280) < ZSM-5(80) < ZSM-5(23). Successive dehydrogenations of n-butane to butadiene (BD) requires the adsorption of intermediate 1-butene, which requires both weak and moderate acid sites, whereas strong acid sites lead to cracking products. The basicity of metal-loaded catalysts was measured using the CO2-TPD technique as presented in Fig. 11 (a) and (b). CO2-TPD exhibited two main peaks, one at 165-300 °C and the other around 400 °C, corresponding to weak-moderate and strong basic sites, respectively, resulting from the interaction between surface hydroxyl groups with CO2. As shown in Figure 11 (a), Ni-Bi-O/Beta and Ni-Bi-O/USY catalysts showed a large weak-moderate basic sites with a little strong-basic sites, while Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 catalyst shows only a large strong-basic sites. As shown in Figure 11 (b), the large strong-basic sites of Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 catalysts changed to weak-moderate basic sites with the increase of SiO2/Al2O3 ratio. For effective catalytic performance, a balanced between the acidic and basic sites is required. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Schematic route for n-butane conversion Scheme 1 proposes a route for converting n-butane into various high-value basic chemicals. The reactant (n-butane) is converted to products mainly through successive dehydrogenations (1st and 2nd) to butadiene (BD), or via cracking to ethylene and propylene or via partial oxidation (PO) to syngas (H2 and CO). 3.2.2 Synergistic role of Ni and Bi species To confirm the synergistic role of Ni and Bi species during the oxidative conversion of n-butane; ZSM-5(280) support, Ni and Bi sole metal oxides on ZSM-5(280) catalysts, and bimetallic Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(280) catalyst were tested at 450°C. The results are presented in Table 4 . At the selected reaction conditions, ZSM-5(280) was less active and mainly selective towards partial oxidation and cracking products, due to its acidic sites. The main products are CO (36.7 %), and C2 = + C3 = (30.3 %). 1st step dehydrogenation selectivity to butenes is 23.4 % with only 3.3 % selectivity to butadiene. This reveals that ZSM-5 catalyst is not selective for successive dehydrogenations due to lack of mobile lattice oxygen species and balanced acid-basic sites. The NiO/ZSM-5 catalyst was predominantly active for PO to methane and syngas (CO and H2), which agreed with Ni supported catalysts popularly used for methanation. At the reaction condition, CH4 and CO had selectivities of 21.4 % and 76.6 %. The catalyst deactivated fast due to lack of sustained redox cycle. This challenge is typical of Ni based catalysts, especially during steam and dry reforming reactions. On the other hand, the BiOx/ZSM-5 catalyst was selective for syngas as over-reaction through dehydrogenation and cracking routes. The selectivity to CO was 53.4 % with 44.8 % selectivity to olefinic products. However, bimetallic Ni-Bi-O supported catalyst presented a synergistic effect towards mainly olefinic products (90 % selectivity) with 70 % selectivity to dehydrogenation products (butenes and butadiene). Also, both 1st and 2nd dehydrogenation selectivities were effective using this catalyst. The synergistic effect contributed in suppressing the over-reaction to undesired reactions by both NiO and BiOx species. The selective oxygen supply from BiOx species to the NiO species and consumption, led to a controlled and sustained redox cycle which is vital for the olefinic selectivity. 3.2.3 Effect of zeolite species Microporous zeolite supports have structured silica sites and uniform silica chain. These properties enabled their cooperation with active species of BiOx, thereby forming bismuth silicate species, which are accountable for the dispersion of the active species in the catalysts. The effects of NiO and BiOx species supported on Beta, USY, and ZSM-5(80) on n-butane conversion are presented in Table 5 . The conversion of n-butane increased with the increase in temperature for all the three catalysts. At both temperatures (450 and 500 °C), conversion over Beta zeolite supported catalyst was higher than that of USY and ZSM-5(80) catalysts. This is ascribed to the high dispersion of active species over the Beta zeolite support. Catalyst selectivity to dehydrogenation products (both 1st and 2nd step dehydrogenations) increased in the order: Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 < Ni-Bi-O/Beta < Ni-Bi-O/USY. The selectivity of the over-reaction to syngas was high for Ni-Bi-O/Beta at both temperatures. Ni-Bi-O/Beta and Ni-Bi-O/USY have balanced acidic-basic sites suitable for dehydrogenation reactions, while Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 has strong acidic sites suitable for cracking reactions. This is evident from the lower selectivities to cracking products (C1-C3, C2 = and C3 =) by the Beta and USY supported catalysts, while on the contrary, ZSM-5 supported catalyst has high selectivity to those products. This performance correlated well with the NH3 and CO2 TPD measurements. The high selectivity to syngas was due to the high oxidative activity of Bi2SiO5, which is commonly the main Bi silicate in the three catalysts. The selectivity to the olefinic products decreased with temperature for both catalysts and is in turn balanced by the increase in the selectivity to CO, due to further oxidation (over-reaction) of the cracking and dehydrogenation products at higher temperature. 3.2.4 Effect ZSM-5 SiO2/Al2O3 ratio The formation of Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20 species in the NiO and BiOx loaded ZSM-5 catalysts was influenced by SiO2/Al2O3 ratio, as evidenced from XRD measurements. The interaction of these species with the active NiO, determine the products selectivities in the oxidative conversion of n-butane. Table 6 summarizes the findings obtained for different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios in the ZSM-5 supported catalysts. The conversions increased with temperature for Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 23, 80 and 280) up to around 7 % increment. However, for Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500), the conversion slightly decreased when the temperature was increased from 450 to 500°C. The selectivity of the over-reaction to syngas was dominant over the ZSM-5(23) catalyst. It was suppressed by increasing the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio from 80 to 1500. However, the ZSM-5(1500) catalyst exhibit high activity and selectivity for the oxidative cracking of n-butane to ethylene/propylene (up to 60.7 %). Interestingly, the ZSM-5(280) catalyst showed the best performance for selective conversion to olefinic products. The olefinic selectivity over NiO-Bi12SiO20-Bi2SiO5/ZSM-5(280) catalyst was 86.9 % (ethylene/propylene: 28.3 % and C4 olefins: 58.6 %) at 500°C and feed molar ratio of O2/n-butane = 2.0. This is due to the effective interaction of NiO with the equivalent amount of Bi12SiO20 and Bi2SiO5 phases, as revealed by the XRD measurement. Fig. 12 shows the relationship between aluminum (Al) content of the zeolite support and selectivity to: carbon monoxide, dry gas (methane, ethane and propane), lower olefins (ethylene and propylene), dehydrogenation products (butenes and butadiene) and 2nd step dehydrogenation product (butadiene). The selectivity trends are valley-type for carbon monoxide and dry gas, and mountain type for dehydrogenates and butadiene, while the selectivity for ethylene and propylene varies depending on the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of the zeolite. Activity, selectivity, and long-term stability of the catalyst are key-parameters for evaluating the performance correctly. It is known that acidic zeolite catalysts with ca. 2.0 mmol/g acidity tend to deactivate rapidly due to coke formation at more than 550 °C. However, the Bi- and Ni-incorporated zeolites were stable due to a much lower acidity (less than 0.05 mmol/g) and the oxygen supplied as co-feed, even though noticeable catalyst deactivation was observed only at 500 °C. It was assumed that the deactivation was caused by coke formation on metallic Ni species produced by H2/hydrocarbon reduction with reduced oxygen supply. 3.2.5 Effect of Bi12SiO20 and Bi2SiO5 phases The degree of formation of Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20 species in the Ni and Bi loaded zeolite catalyst, coupled with their interaction with the active NiO, were accountable for the catalyst's activity and selectivity during n-butane oxidative conversion. Fig. 13 shows the plots of activity (conversion) and selectivity (butenes and butadiene) against the percentage of Bi12SiO20 phase in the Bi silicates as obtained from the XRD measurements. The activity increased with the increase of Bi12SiO20. This result agreed with high reducibility (redox ability) of NiO-Bi12SiO20 as shown in TPR measurement. The selectivity of dehydrogenates and butadiene increased and then decreased after reaching maximum selectivity. These findings revealed that the moderate amount of Bi12SiO20 and Bi2SiO5 interacts effectively with NiO forming NiO-Bi2SiO5/Bi12SiO20, which improved the selectivity. The performance of the prepared catalysts was compared with other reported catalysts in the open literature for the oxidative conversion of n-butane as presented in Table 7 . The product selectivities were compared at approximately an iso-conversion of n-butane. McDermott et al. [44] reported 40.8% selectivity to C4 olefins at 550°C using a hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) catalyst, with 22.3% and 26.0% selectivity to ethylene and propylene, respectively. The selectivities to various products were primarily controlled by the n-butane to oxygen feed ratio, with O2 lean conditions favoring cracking selectivity. Kijima et al. [45] utilized layered BiOCl and LaOCl catalysts for the oxidative cracking of n-butane. The BiOCl catalyst had a selectivity of 49.1% for C4 olefins, 16.8% for ethylene, and 11.3% for propylene. However, LaOCl catalyst provided 77.4% selectivity to COx products due to the formation of highly selective activated oxygen species for the deep oxidation of n-butane. Setnicka et al. [46] used hexagonal mesoporous titanosilicates to support vanadium oxide for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane. The V-19Ti-HMS catalyst produced 44% C4 olefins and 53% COx selectivities. In this study, Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(280) and Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500) catalysts gave 58.6% C4 olefins, 19.3% ethylene, 9.0% propylene, 10.9% COx and 17.1% C4 olefins, 43.2% ethylene, 17.5% propylene, 13.4% COx, respectively. The developed catalysts performed better than those reported in terms of olefinic selectivity. The present study revealed that, the different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios in the ZSM-5 supported catalysts, controlled the proportion of the Bi silicate species formed. These species controlled the oxygen mobility to the active NiO species, which in turn determine the product selectivities and the favorable reaction pathway; dehydrogenation or cracking. 4 Conclusions A catalyst system comprising nanocomposite oxides of Ni and Bi having Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20 phases on Beta, USY and ZSM-5 were successfully synthesized using nitrate co-impregnation method with two-step calcination. The two phases were obtained depending on the zeolite species and its SiO2/Al2O3 ratio. The nanocomposite catalysts of Ni-Bi-Si oxides containing both Bi12SiO20 and Bi2SiO5, exhibited high activity and selectivity for the oxidative conversion of n-butane to butadiene, ethylene/propylene or syngas. The zeolites worked 1) indirectly for the redox control of NiO-BiOx oxides due to their structured/uniform silica sites and 2) directly for the acidity control of the catalyst. The results showed that the selectivity to butadiene, ethylene/propylene or syngas over Ni-Bi-O/zeolite depended on mixed ratio of the specific Bi-Si oxides (Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20). The main products were butadiene and syngas over Beta or USY catalysts, with ethylene/propylene and syngas over ZSM-5 catalyst. The main product changed along SiO2/Al2O3 ratio to syngas over Al-rich ZSM-5, butenes/butadiene over Si-rich ZSM-5, and ethylene/propylene over high Si ZSM-5. The activity increased with the increase in the Bi12SiO20 phase, in agreement with the high reducibility (redox ability). The moderate amount of the Bi12SiO20 improved the selectivity to dehydrogenates and butadiene while the excess amount made the side reaction: partial oxidation to syngas, dominant. coredata.dc:description: The on-purpose production of butadiene and light olefins via oxidative conversion of n-butane was investigated over nanocomposites of Ni-Bi-Si oxides comprising Bi12SiO20/Bi2SiO5 phase regulated with silica of Beta, USY and ZSM-5 zeolites. Different ratios of Bi12SiO20 and Bi2SiO5 phases were obtained depending on the zeolite species and its SiO2/Al2O3 ratio. The Ni-Bi-Si oxides were characterized by X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, etc. to examine the electronic state and oxygen mobility in specific Bi-Si oxides; Bi2SiO5 and Bi12SiO20. The active species-zeolites interaction controlled the reducibility of Ni-Bi-O system and acidity of the catalysts. Ni-Bi-O/ZSM-5(1500) catalyst exhibited high selectivity for the oxidative conversion of n-butane to ethylene and propylene (60.7 wt. %) at 16 % conversion. Similarly, the olefinic selectivity over NiO-Bi12SiO20-Bi2SiO5/ZSM-5(280) catalyst at 20 % conversion, was 87 % (ethylene and propylene = 28.3 %, C4 olefins = 58.6 % including BD = 20 %) at 500°C and feed ratio of O2/n-butane = 2.0.
coredata.dc:title: Production of butadiene and lower olefins via oxidative conversion of n-butane over Ni-Bi-O/zeolite catalysts
